head.title: 3D GIS and ‘The Royaltie Of Sight’: Recreating ‘Prospects’ and ‘Perspectives’ within an English designed landscape c. 1550–1660 | Digital Scholarship in the Humanities | Oxford Academic

div.h1: 3D GIS and ‘The Royaltie Of Sight’: Recreating ‘Prospects’ and ‘Perspectives’ within an English designed landscape c. 1550–1660

div.div:
School of History, University of East Anglia, Norwich,
UK
Correspondence: Elizabeth Stewart, School of History, University of East Anglia, Norwich, UK. E-mail:lizzie.stewart@uea.ac.uk; elizabeth.er.stewart@gmail.com
Search for other works by this author on:
Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 34, Issue Supplement_1, December 2019, Pages i179–i189, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqz043

div.p: Elizabeth Stewart, 3D GIS and ‘The Royaltie Of Sight’: Recreating ‘Prospects’ and ‘Perspectives’ within an English designed landscape c. 1550–1660, Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 34, Issue Supplement_1, December 2019, Pages i179–i189, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqz043

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

section.p: Experience through sight has been recognized as a contributing factor in the shaping of historic landscapes, where humans could express themselves in response to their aesthetic and intellectual qualities. What was experienced, however, was not only dependent on the ‘prospect’, or landscape view, but also on the individual ‘perspective’ of the spectator. Three-dimensional Geographical Information Systems (3D GIS) has enabled investigations into landscape visibility within digitized historic environments and can therefore assist the analysis and understanding of this phenomenon. This article applies 3D GIS to a currently under-researched area of landscape history, English designed landscapes of the 16th and 17th centuries. From country houses and gardens to parks and working estates, these landscapes were manipulated in response to the landowners’ ‘perspectives’ towards the landscape, which subsequently determined the visibility or invisibility of features within certain ‘prospects’. This concept was dubbed ‘The Royaltie of Sight’ by Henry Wotton in 1624. By using 3D GIS to recreate a designed landscape that poses challenges which have previously hindered its analysis, the characteristics of ‘prospects’ can be ascertained using viewshed analysis and the individual ‘perspective’ of the landowner interpreted using phenomenology and reception theory. The results presented in this article demonstrate how 3D GIS has benefited studies into English designed landscapes and improved knowledge of how perception influenced landscape change.

div.p: As one of humanity’s guiding senses, sight plays a crucial role in how we experience the world, and thus has a strong connection to landscape change throughout history (Cosgrove, 2008, p. 2). Such was evident in the English designed landscapes of the 16th and 17th centuries. Owned by the upper echelons of contemporary society, each estate encapsulated the fashionable European style of landscape design. Its distinctly geometric appearance respected certain visual principles that were intended to be observed within a ‘prospect’, or landscape view which contemporaries enjoyed from certain positions across the estate (Strong, 1998, p. 118). However, each estate was unique in terms of location, topography, and ownership. As a result, ‘the Properties of a well-chosen Prospect’, or the inclusion or exclusion of landscape features within a view, was tailored to the landowners’ individual personalities, preferences, and ‘perspectives’. This concept is what 17th-century architectural theorist Henry Wotton dubbed ‘The Royaltie of Sight’ (Wotton, 1624, p. 4).

From literary, art and garden history to architectural, archaeological, and landscape studies, numerous disciplines have investigated designed landscapes (Harris, 1979; Strong, 1998; Henderson, 2005; Strong, 2005; Dix, 2011). However, research has been hindered by certain challenges evident at Stiffkey Old Hall, an estate in Norfolk, and the case study of this article. First, designed landscapes from this period rarely exist wholly intact. Stiffkey became partially ruined by 1780, while the estate landscape was modernized. Therefore, the ‘properties’ of the ‘prospects’ that were once enjoyed at Stiffkey no longer exist. Secondly, the inability to access sites presents further problems. Stiffkey is privately owned, which makes it difficult both to acquire data from extant features and experience the estate first-hand, despite what evidence still survives. Thirdly, our understanding of designed landscapes is arguably biased towards more renowned or grander estates. Stiffkey, however, belonged to Nathaniel Bacon, a member of the lesser elite as the second son of Nicholas Bacon. By using Stiffkey for this case study, these issues are addressed and, where possible, rectified.

GIS is a leading technique within studies of ancient and historic landscapes (Wheatley and Gillings, 2003; Chapman, 2006; Conolly and Lake, 2006). Its viewshed analysis tool, which calculates landscape visibility, has also aided research into experiences within such landscapes (Llobera, 2007) including 18th-century English designed landscapes (Spooner, 2009; Dalton, 2012). When GIS is combined with computer-aided design (CAD), three-dimensional Geographical Information Systems (3D GIS) has demonstrated reconstructive and analytical proficiency in this area (Richards-Rissetto, 2017). Its application to English designed landscapes, however, is still in its infancy (Stewart, 2015). In this study, 3D GIS became a digital conduit for integrating available primary sources and the aforementioned disciplinary approaches. The visibility of ‘prospects’, calculated using viewshed analysis, was able to be visualized within the digitally recreated landscape context of Stiffkey from the late-16th to early-17th centuries. Subsequently, this new technological resource provided data to help ascertain Nathaniel Bacon’s ‘perspective’ towards the landscape. An adapted combination of phenomenology and reception theory was used to interpret the results. By engaging with the 3D GIS landscape through immersion alongside evidence from literary texts, artworks, and other estates that were potentially encountered, how the landscape was received can be determined. Therefore, 3D GIS has the capabilities to advance research and develop understanding of English designed landscapes and of contemporary perceptions within them.

The methodology involved three main phases: (1) recreating Stiffkey within 3D GIS; (2) calculating viewsheds; and (3) interpreting the ‘prospects’ and Nathaniel Bacon’s ‘perspective’. First, recreating Stiffkey as a 3D GIS visualization required investigations into available evidence. An archaeological earthwork plan records the original terraced gardens (Taigel and Williamson, 1991, p. 96), which survive within the modernized grounds of the partially ruined hall (Fig. 1). Archival sources also survive at the Norfolk Record Office and the Folger Shakespeare Library, Washington DC. These sources include a 16th-century architectural plan (Osborne, n.d.) and a 17th-century estate map (Anonymous, n.d.). From these diverse yet physically dispersed sources, their data were integrated into one potential recreation of Stiffkey within 3D GIS.

img.alt: Stiffkey Old Hall, Norfolk ©John Fielding Aerial Image

div.p: Stiffkey Old Hall, Norfolk ©John Fielding Aerial Image

img.alt: Stiffkey Old Hall, Norfolk ©John Fielding Aerial Image

div.p: Stiffkey Old Hall, Norfolk ©John Fielding Aerial Image

Using Esri’s ArcGIS 10.3 standard GIS software, polygons were digitized to represent individual landscape features, determined from the geo-referenced map, architectural, and earthwork plans. These were supported by landscape evidence documented on Ordnance Survey maps and aerial photography, obtained from EDINA Digimap.1 The process was completed within a 2,000-acre focus area which accounted for the horizon line, thus encompassing any landscape features that could potentially influence a ‘prospect’ (Fig. 2).

img.alt: Polygons within Focus Area of Stiffkey

div.p: Polygons within Focus Area of Stiffkey

img.alt: Polygons within Focus Area of Stiffkey

div.p: Polygons within Focus Area of Stiffkey

However, written sources including personal papers (Hassell Smith et al., 1979) and estate accounts (Kemp, n.d.; Bacon, n.d.) also provide valuable descriptions, which the simplistic nature of polygons cannot capture. Therefore, using Autodesk’s 3DS MAX, CAD models were created to account for both extant and absent features. These were built upon COLLADA-exported multipatch files, which represented the topographical footprint for the models by interpolating polygons with Triangulated Irregular Network data. Once completed, the CAD models were converted into GIS-compatible 3D studio (.3ds) files for importation. These models were geo-referenced and stored within a geodatabase, thus completing the 3D GIS visualization. Altogether, this process is time-consuming and data-intensive, depending on available sources but also the landscape area being recreated. Nevertheless, the completed 3D GIS visualization provides a more detailed but also editable landscape representation to improve examination and comprehension into how Stiffkey was perceived (Fig. 3).
Comparing polygons (left) to CAD models (right)
Comparing polygons (left) to CAD models (right)

The second phase involved calculating the viewsheds to determine visibility within these ‘prospects’. First, the locations from which ‘prospects’ were to be analysed required identification. From the windowed rooms of the hall to natural and artificial platforms amongst the grounds, many opportunities were designed into these landscapes to enjoy a ‘prospect’ (Henderson, 2005, p. 19). However, each estate was different. At Stiffkey, vantage points included a garden building, the hall’s gallery and its great chamber. The ‘prospects’ from them are the focus of this article. These locations were defined as point data, which recorded the height of the person or window within an attribute table. Viewshed analysis then estimated landscape visibility from those locations using a Digital Elevation Model (DEM). Obtained from EDINA Digimap, a 2-m resolution LiDAR-derived2 Digital Terrain Model (DTM), excluding modern surface data, was the most accurate available with optimum coverage over the focus area. However, before conducting the viewshed analysis, surface data needed to be added onto the DTM to create a DEM which replicated the 3D GIS visualization. This required converting height-attributed polygons, representing both natural and artificial features, into raster data. Outputted to match the 2-m accuracy of the DTM, the rasterized polygons were incorporated into the DTM using the following Raster Calculator formula:

A DEM was produced which resembled the heights and layout of the 3D GIS landscape upon its intended topographical elevation (Fig. 4). Once completed, the viewshed analyses were calculated using the DEM and the results subsequently overlaid onto the 3D GIS visualization for interpretation.
Converting polygons into DEM
Converting polygons into DEM

However, sight is not perception if not considered in accordance with the mind (Eckhart, 1924; Frieman and Gillings, 2007). Therefore, the final methodological phase used phenomenology and reception theory to interpret Nathaniel Bacon’s ‘perspective’. Studies of embodied human experiences within phenomenology can benefit from 3D GIS (Landeschi, 2018, p. 12). However, the exploration of readers’ responses to literary texts within reception theory has yet to be adapted to studies of designed landscapes although it potentially offers ‘exciting and fresh perspectives’ on how sites were experienced (Hunt, 2013, p. 7). Accordingly, this study combines and adapts both approaches by addressing the embodied experiences through immersion alongside an examination of literary texts, artwork, and other sites that were potentially encountered. Therefore, the benefits of these two approaches are demonstrated with the help of 3D GIS. Subsequently, Nathaniel Bacon’s ‘perspective’ behind the ‘prospects’ at Stiffkey can be elucidated. Altogether, 3D GIS allowed the integration of both data and disciplinary approaches into a digital visualization of the layout and designs of the immediate grounds and the rural estate landscape. The subsequent visibility or invisibility of certain features within specific ‘prospects’ can provide insight into how ‘prospects’ and ‘perspectives’ influenced the organization and construction of individual designed landscapes.

At Stiffkey, one key vantage point was the garden building, built upon the uppermost terrace of the Eastern gardens in 1594 (FSL E.b.2, p. 42). According to the viewshed results (Fig. 5), the ‘prospect’ was focused on ‘The Nether Terris’. Adorned with beasts on poles and the black-and-white family colours, the garden emphasized Nathaniel Bacon’s lineage and status (Taigel and Williamson, 1991, p. 95). The display of heraldic symbolism at Stiffkey was potentially inspired by the Whitehall Palace gardens, which were depicted in Henry VIII’s family portrait (British School, c.1545). The overall layout of ‘the Nether Terris’ was better observed from the garden building, and thus rules of geometric perspective controlled the visual experience (Strong, 1998, p. 203). The vertical lines of the poles particularly contrasted against the house in the background. The use of local flint and building techniques created an uncommonly vernacular style of country house compared with other contemporary examples. Francis Bacon, Nathaniel Bacon’s younger brother and also a renowned author, wrote in his essays, Of Gardens and Of Building, about his preference of the garden ‘as the purest of human pleasures’ (Bacon, 1864b, p. 235) over the house, which was ‘built to live in and not to look on’ (Bacon, 1864a, p. 228). Nathaniel Bacon arguably heeded his brother’s advice and thus ensured the garden, and not the house, was the true focus of the ‘prospect’ from the garden building.

img.alt: Viewshed Results from Garden Building, Stiffkey

div.p: Viewshed Results from Garden Building, Stiffkey

img.alt: Viewshed Results from Garden Building, Stiffkey

div.p: Viewshed Results from Garden Building, Stiffkey

However, the bowling green on the lowest terrace was hidden from sight of the garden building. Perhaps, it was an unworthy inclusion within the ‘prospect’, but there is another explanation. During this period, some houses and gardens were designed as one geometric scheme (Henderson, 2005, p. 19). Nathaniel Bacon also implemented this at Stiffkey (Hassell Smith, 2002, p. 172). The geometry of ‘The Nether Terris’ aligned with the hall and other garden courts, thus respecting the harmonic ratios of the scheme. However, the necessary projection for this terrace, upon the steep valley slope, consequently obscured the bowling green from view. Altogether, this ‘prospect’ suggests that Nathaniel Bacon prioritized the order of his geometric scheme over viewing the entire terrace complex, including the Bowling Green, from the garden building.

Wotton also encouraged ‘extent and varietie’ within a ‘prospect’ (Wotton, 1624, p. 4). This was perceptible from the gallery, an important room for entertaining, within the north range with a west-facing window (Fig. 6). The most prominent areas of woodland within Stiffkey were visible along the horizon line. Fashionable within paintings depicting landscapes during this period (Ogden and Ogden, 1955, p. 2), the woodland contributed to the naturally beautiful composition of the valley. However, woods were places of both ‘profit and delight’ (Peacham, 1612, p. 208). Nathaniel Bacon also invested in woodland management, profiting from felling trees for timber and fuel (Bacon, 1979, p. 63). Therefore, the economic value of the estate was likely also promoted through the inclusion of woodland within this ‘prospect’.
Viewshed Results from Gallery, Stiffkey
Viewshed Results from Gallery, Stiffkey

On the other hand, an area of common land was obscured by the valley ridge. Unlike the agricultural fields, this common remained uncultivated and unenclosed until 1793 (Chambers, 1829, p. 598). Enclosed and privatized commons became ‘the richest, most goodly’ land, but unenclosed ones were a ‘blemish in the beauty’ of the landscape that should be ‘cleansed and purged’ along with the commoners or ‘vermin’ who resided there (Moore, 1653). However, it was the topography rather than the actions of Nathaniel Bacon that was responsible for obscuring the common. This illustrates how analysing trends within a variety of ‘prospects’ can help build a more comprehensive picture of Nathaniel Bacon’s attitudes towards the landscape.

However, the manipulability and versatility of 3D GIS also allow viewshed analyses of ‘prospects’ from locations which were designed but were never implemented. This is particularly beneficial regarding the analysis of the gallery, which was the result of a compromise. A courtyard-plan house was intended for Stiffkey, and its entire first floor within the south range was meant for the gallery (Osborne, n.d.). During construction, financial difficulties prevented the south wing from being built and so the gallery was relegated to the North West attic room with only one window (Hassell Smith, 2002, p. 177–9). Therefore, conducting a viewshed analysis from the intended gallery would determine what ‘prospect’ Nathaniel Bacon had initially desired as a comparison. While each window would marginally change the visual perspective, the panoramic view from the central statement window is analysed here.

The results show (Fig. 7) that this more private view also avoided directly overlooking the common but also the village and open fields, which were commonly farmed in strips by the villagers. The interpretation of Nathaniel Bacon’s dislike towards commons but also other commonly managed land is reinforced. Furthermore, Nathaniel Bacon was likely of the opinion that ‘ill markets’ and ‘ill neighbours’ contributed to an ‘ill seat’, or estate, which Francis Bacon believed (Bacon, 1864a, p. 229). This was further evidenced after Nathaniel Bacon demolished parts of the village (Bacon, 1979, pp. 118–119), including one area visible from the gallery, which can be identified as earthworks in the landscape today (Stiffkey Local History Group, 2013, p. 58). Subsequently, Nathaniel Bacon extended his privately owned pasture for grazing sheep (Bacon, 1979, p. 15). This pasture was prominent in the ‘prospect’. It displayed the estate’s productivity but also wealth and status associated with owning sheep, a landlord animal (Overton, 1993, p. 78). As a lower ranking official, Nathaniel Bacon likely considered this important to display to his peers. However, this gallery and its ‘prospect’ were not created. Nonetheless, this interpretation of Nathaniel Bacon’s intentions is valuable to our understanding of him and his estate.

img.alt: Viewshed Results from Intended Gallery, Stiffkey

div.p: Viewshed Results from Intended Gallery, Stiffkey

img.alt: Viewshed Results from Intended Gallery, Stiffkey

div.p: Viewshed Results from Intended Gallery, Stiffkey

The great chamber, which was upon the first floor of the east range, fulfilled the role of this gallery (Fig. 8). It provided a secluded view over the pasture in the opposing direction to the village, fields and common. The room also had the advantage of an elevated ‘prospect’ over not only ‘the Nether Terris’ but the entire geometric scheme including the bowling green, which Nathaniel Bacon had prioritized. This scheme also extended to the forecourts, which could have been observed from the south gallery had it been built (Fig. 7). As Francis Bacon stated, ‘gardens shew best from an Upper window’ but also from the ‘Tarras’, upon which the garden building stood (Bacon, 1626, p. 58). Altogether, Nathaniel Bacon effectively ensured aesthetic and intellectually stimulating ‘prospects’ best showcased the features he considered important at Stiffkey.

img.alt: Viewshed Results from Great Chamber, Stiffkey

div.p: Viewshed Results from Great Chamber, Stiffkey

img.alt: Viewshed Results from Great Chamber, Stiffkey

div.p: Viewshed Results from Great Chamber, Stiffkey

The results presented here are from a selection of ‘prospects’ that were analysed within Stiffkey from the late-16th to early-17th centuries. Using 3D GIS combined with historical data and cultural context from the 16th and 17th centuries, Nathaniel Bacon’s ‘perspective’ can be interpreted. His desire to exhibit familial prestige, follow fashions in geometric landscape design, and emphasize his wealth and status was evident. He was also keen to demonstrate economic productivity, but also maintain his privacy and conceal common or unmanageable areas. As a result, this analysis has provided new insights into historical perceptions of the beauty or worth of landscape features within a ‘prospect’. Its subsequent influence over the configuration of Stiffkey has also improved. Therefore, despite hindrances concerning landscape change and site access, 3D GIS has enabled the variety of evidence and different disciplinary approaches to collectively contribute to our understanding of this lesser known designed landscape and its owner.

To conclude, this research demonstrates how 3D GIS can facilitate the enhancement of knowledge regarding what contemporaries experienced within designed landscapes. It also opens possibilities to explore and analyse not only what existed, but what was proposed and not executed in reality. However, Wotton’s ‘Royaltie of Sight’ not only addressed a ‘Lordship of the Eye’ from a stationary ‘prospect’, but also a ‘Lordship of the Feete’ (Wotton, 1624, p. 4), whereby experiencing the landscape through movement was also important (Hunt, 2013, p. 145). Therefore, in future work, experimentation with animations within 3D GIS could provide another layer of analysis to examine this phenomenon. Altogether, this study benefits research on English designed landscapes from the 16th and 17th centuries, especially into sites with inaccessible, fragmentary, or absent evidence. The capabilities of 3D GIS have also been demonstrated. Acting as a digital conduit for integrating the diverse range of evidence and disciplinary approaches, 3D GIS provides a progressive and non-invasive technique of exploring, analysing, conserving, and accessing historic landscapes.
EDINA Digimap is an online map and data delivery service which includes access to Ordnance Survey and historical maps, aerial photography, and LiDAR data.
LiDAR stands for ‘Light Detection and Ranging’ data, a highly accurate type of topographical dataset in a rasterized format, which is surveyed using laser light.
